user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of parse_http_version:
```c
static bool
parse_http_version (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                    const char *http_string,
                    size_t len)
{
  const char *const h = http_string; /**< short alias */
  mhd_assert (NULL != http_string);

  /* String must start with 'HTTP/d.d', case-sensetive match.
   * See https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9112#name-http-version */
  if ((HTTP_VER_LEN != len) ||
      ('H' != h[0]) || ('T' != h[1]) || ('T' != h[2]) || ('P' != h[3]) ||
      ('/' != h[4])
      || ('.' != h[6]) ||
      (('0' > h[5]) || ('9' < h[5])) ||
      (('0' > h[7]) || ('9' < h[7])))
  {
    connection->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_INVALID;
    transmit_error_response_static (connection,
                                    MHD_HTTP_BAD_REQUEST,
                                    REQUEST_MALFORMED);
    return false;
  }
  if (1 == h[5] - '0')
  {
    /* HTTP/1.x */
    if (1 == h[7] - '0')
      connection->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_1_1;
    else if (0 == h[7] - '0')
      connection->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_1_0;
    else
      connection->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_1_2__1_9;

    return true;
  }

  if (0 == h[5] - '0')
  {
    /* Too old major version */
    connection->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_TOO_OLD;
    transmit_error_response_static (connection,
                                    MHD_HTTP_HTTP_VERSION_NOT_SUPPORTED,
                                    REQ_HTTP_VER_IS_TOO_OLD);
    return false;
  }

  connection->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_FUTURE;
  transmit_error_response_static (connection,
                                  MHD_HTTP_HTTP_VERSION_NOT_SUPPORTED,
                                  REQ_HTTP_VER_IS_NOT_SUPPORTED);
  return false;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No pointer-to-non-const occurrences that need investigation were found. Specifically:
- The input string parameter is declared as const char *http_string, and the local alias is const char *const h — both already point to const-qualified data.
- The only other pointer parameter is struct MHD_Connection *connection; this must remain non-const because the function assigns to connection->rq.http_ver and passes the connection to transmit_error_response_static (which presumably mutates or relies on a mutable connection). Making the pointed-to type const would prevent these legitimate modifications.
- No other pointer variables or pointer targets appear in the function.
Therefore, there are no fragments in this function that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 that require investigation.
